summary: rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus (RHDV) is a highly contagious disease characterized by acute liver damage and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) the first outbreak of RHD was reported in 1984 in the Jiangsu Province of China (Zhu et al., 2016) this has quickly spread to most parts of the world. the liver is believed to be the main site of RHDV reproduction. systemic hemorrhagic diathesis and DIC can lead to rabbit death. this is most likely consequences of liver cell loss through RHDV-induced apoptosis. studies have indicated that N-acetyl cysteine (San-Miguel et al., 2006), cardiotrophin (Tunon et al., 2011b), and melatonin (Tunon et al., 2011a) can attenuate liver damage and prolong survival in RHDV-infected rabbits. this is likely due to the induction of various anti-apoptotic factors and their inherent anti-apoptotic effects rabbit kidney cells (RK13), human liver cancer cells (HepG2) and human cervical cancer cells (HeLa) were purchased from the American Tissue Culture Collection (ATCC; Manassas, VA, United States) they were cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM; Gibco; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, United States) cells were transfected with pcDNA3.1-NSP6, H27N, D44G, C104G, or pcDNA 3.1-6 his vector for 12 h in 6-well culture plates. the cells were then fixed with chilled 95% ethanol for 10 min at 4 C and washed three times with PBS plus Tween-20 (PBST) the plates were analyzed via fluorescence microscopy (Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany) cell viability assay An MTT cell proliferation and cytotoxicity assay kit was used to detect any potential effects of NSP6 on cell proliferation according to manufacturer’s instructions. the cells were then washed with PBS and resuspended in 100 L binding buffer supplemented with 5 L annexin V (10 g/mL) and 5 L propidium iodide (PI) (20 g/mg) for 10 min in the dark. the samples were immediately screened using flow cytometry.
